qas.question: Who made it next to impossible to learn about their heritage for African Americans?
Slaves were not allowed to do what?

answers.text: to learn to read and write

qas.question: What did Indigenous Americans not do that makes it difficult to trace their heritage?

answers.text: spoke English, nor read or wrote it

qas.question: What factors did not affect racial solidarity amoung African Americans?

answers.text: their multiracial admixture, or social/economic stratification

qas.question: What was a factor in ethnic solidarity for whites?
Who was the one-drop rule not a significant factor for?
Who found it easy to learn about their Indigenous American heritage?
Who was forthcoming with genealogical information?
Who was encouraged to read and write?

context: For <b6_0>African Americans<b6_0/>, <a0_0><b5_0>the one-drop rule<b5_0/><a0_0/> was a significant factor in ethnic solidarity. African Americans generally shared a common cause in society regardless of <a4_0>their multiracial admixture, or social/economic stratification<a4_0/>. Additionally, <b7_0>African Americans<b7_0/> found it, near, impossible to learn about their Indigenous American heritage as many <a1_0><b8_0>family elders<b8_0/><a1_0/> withheld pertinent genealogical information. Tracing the genealogy of African Americans can be a very difficult process, especially for descendants of Indigenous Americans, because <b9_0>African Americans<b9_0/> who were slaves were forbidden <a2_0>to learn to read and write<a2_0/>, and a majority of Indigenous Americans neither <a3_0>spoke English, nor read or wrote it<a3_0/>.
